hero_description: Master the art of writing meaningful commit messages that make your Git history clean, readable, and professional.
overview_description: Conventional Commits is a specification for adding human and machine readable meaning to commit messages. It provides an easy set of rules for creating an explicit commit history, which makes it easier to write automated tools on top of.
overview_benefits_list: Communicate the nature of changes to team members
Make it easier for people to contribute to your projects
types_description: Learn about the different types of commits and when to use them
type_feat_description: A new feature for the user
type_style_description: Changes that do not affect the meaning of the code
type_refactor_description: A code change that neither fixes a bug nor adds a feature
type_perf_description: A code change that improves performance
type_test_description: Adding missing tests or correcting existing tests
type_test_example: test: add unit tests for user service
type_build_description: Changes that affect the build system or external dependencies
type_ci_description: Changes to our CI configuration files and scripts
type_chore_description: Other changes that don't modify src or test files
practices_description: Follow these guidelines to write effective conventional commits
practices_commit_description: Structure your commit messages for maximum clarity
practices_scope_description: Use scopes to provide additional context
practices_body_description: Write clear and descriptive commit bodies
practices_footer_description: Use footers for breaking changes and issue references
examples_description: See how conventional commits are used in practice
advanced_breaking_description: Handle breaking changes properly in your commits
overview_description: Conventional Commits is a specification for adding human and machine readable meaning to commit messages. It provides an easy set of rules for creating an explicit commit history, which makes it easier to write automated tools on top of.
